#summary Papers describing different aspects of ADDA.

Development of *ADDA* is mostly performed in the framework of scientific projects. In the following, a list of publications, relevant to different parts of *ADDA*, is presented. These publications contain detailed information about corresponding parts. We also recommend one to select papers from this list for citation in publications that use *ADDA*.

<wiki:toc />

= General description =

M. A. Yurkin and A. G. Hoekstra,“The discrete-dipole-approximation code ADDA: capabilities and known limitations,” [http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2011.01.031 J. Quant. Spectrosc. Radiat. In press].

= Specific aspects =
== OpenCL (GPU-accelerated) version ==
M. Huntemannn, G. Heygster, and G. Hong, “Discrete dipole approximation simulations on GPUs using OpenCL - Application on cloud ice particles,” [http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jocs.2011.05.011 J. Comput. Sci. In press].

== Particles much larger than the wavelength ==
M. A. Yurkin, V. P. Maltsev, and A. G. Hoekstra, “The discrete dipole approximation for simulation of light scattering by particles much larger than the wavelength,” [http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jqsrt.2007.01.033 J. Quant. Spectrosc. Radiat. Transfer 106, 546-557 (2007)].

== Gold nanoparticles ==
M. A. Yurkin, D. de Kanter, and A. G. Hoekstra, “Accuracy of the discrete dipole approximation for simulation of optical properties of gold nanoparticles,” [http://dx.doi.org/10.1117/1.3335329 J. Nanophoton. 4, 041585-15 (2010)].

== Extreme refractive indices and the FCD formulation ==
M. A. Yurkin, M. Min, and A. G. Hoekstra, “Application of the discrete dipole approximation to very large refractive indices: Filtered coupled dipoles revived,” [http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevE.82.036703 Phys. Rev. E 82, 036703-12 (2010)].

== Granulated particles ==
M. A. Yurkin, K. A. Semyanov, V. P. Maltsev, and A. G. Hoekstra, “Discrimination of granulocyte subtypes from light scattering: theoretical analysis using a granulated sphere model,” [http://dx.doi.org/10.1364/OE.15.016561 Opt. Express 15, 16561-16580 (2007)].

== Radiation forces ==
A. G. Hoekstra, M. Frijlink, L. B. F. M. Waters, and P. M. A. Sloot, “Radiation forces in the discrete-dipole approximation,” [http://dx.doi.org/10.1364/JOSAA.18.001944 J. Opt. Soc. Am. A 18, 1944-1953 (2001)].

== Internal fields ==
A. G. Hoekstra, J. Rahola, and P. M. A. Sloot, “Accuracy of internal fields in volume integral equation simulations of light scattering,” [http://dx.doi.org/10.1364/AO.37.008482 Appl. Opt. 37, 8482-8497 (1998)].

 * K. V. Gilev, E. Eremina, M. A. Yurkin, and V. P. Maltsev, “Comparison of the discrete dipole approximation and the discrete source method for simulation of light scattering by red blood cells,” [http://dx.doi.org/10.1364/OE.18.005681 Opt. Express 18, 5681-5690 (2010)].
